Of course I meant you Andres!
Jets or Giants?!=A0 LOL!!=A0 Even better, not=
 as far to come.=A0 You'll still have
to get a passport so you can travel t=
o hostile evil empire of Canada. Bay of
Fundy is in my backyard so we can g=
o kayaking.
I'll pick you up in St. Stephen when you cross over from Calais=
. August and
September are the best months here.=A0All you need to bring is=
 your Nihonto
knowledge.
=A0
Talk to you soon. Have a great New Years Eve.
=
=A0
Mark
P.S. Say hello to Dick Clark for me
=A0

Mark,

If the Andres you refer to is me, I'm as New Yorker as the=
y come, not
international at all. I work in Manhattan and live in the Pocon=
os. :)

Beer and lobster sounds great. Just pick a date... I've always mean=
t
to go take a look at New Brunswick, especially Fundy Bay. Heard good
stuf=
f about it.

If you didn't mean me, then too late, I'm still going.

Dewa,
=

Andres

At 08:52 AM 12/23/2005, you wrote:
>Hi John,
>=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 Has Christmas come early?!=A0 I could have sworn it w=
as only
>friday!
>You're telling me you know of contacts in Canada for stud=
y and collection?
>Well Merry Christmas to me!=A0 LOL
>I live in New Brunsw=
ick on the east coast. Occasionally I'll make it out
>west to do some mount=
ain climbing and I've been down to New Hampshire,
Mount
>Washington. Apart =
from that, I usually don't get state side. I can just see
>myself trying to=
 explain to a customs officer that I'm travelling to the
>U.S. to attend a =
Japanese Sword Show! LOL! I'm going to need a passport
next
>year just to c=
ross the border into Maine so I can buy cheap milk!
>Where abouts=A0 are yo=
u located John?
>Any information you can provide me with would be greatly a=
ppreciated. If
>anyone out there in Nihonto land wants to come to New Bruns=
wick and share
>their knowledge, I will supply Beer and Lobsters.
>Now if t=
here's going to be more than 10 of you or any international
>arrivals, (And=
res), I will need some time to plan.
>Have a great holiday season everyone.=
 It's been great listening to your
>banter.
>
>Mark
>

ow THAT

regards, Mark

oups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On

ent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 10:04 PM

m

>Anthony -
=
>
>Sorry to sound like such a "merchant" but if you're interested I can sen=
d
>you some pictures of a very nice selection of good quality iron tsuba th=
at
>I'm selling. Most are $200 range, more or less. If you are new at this =
I
>would be happy to recommend good ones that would help teach you about th=
ese
>things. Some of these have been to a number of shows and are now kept =
home
>so that I can keep my table at the shows, fresh. All are authentic, f=
or
>sure. The shows seem to have a wonderful selection of nice quality tsub=
a
>these days and that is good for the buyer, bad for the seller since ther=
e
is
>such a "selection" to pick from. Anyway...just thought I'd toss this =
idea
>out to you. I've been around for going on 40 years...gosh, that's a l=
ittle
>frightening to put in writing!
>
>Ron
>STL

>Hello,
>
>I'm new here and to collecting Tsuba. Where do you buy your=
 Tsuba from?

arch, an

like

>only way to be really sure of authenticity is to purchase papered
>Tsuba,=
 but because I'm starting off I want some sources of authentic

reasonably priced. Any suggestions?
>
